note.#text: 1919 Gansevoort-Lansing, Catherine; Ann P. Hays; John and Carolyn De Marco (Lyrical Ballad Bookstore); etc. Gift and purchase

The Gansevoorts and the Lansings were two of the original Dutch families to settle in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys of New York State. Other families who intermarried with the Gansevoorts and the Lansings were the Melvilles, Sanfords and Van Schaicks. Members of these families were prominent in politics, the military, literature, law, politics, medicine, and economics.
MSS 85M84

note.#text: 1919 Gansevoort-Lansing, Catherine; Ann P. Hays; John and Carolyn De Marco (Lyrical Ballad Bookstore); etc. Gift and purchase

The Gansevoorts and the Lansings were two of the original Dutch families to settle in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys of New York State. Other families who intermarried with the Gansevoorts and the Lansings were the Melvilles, Sanfords and Van Schaicks. Members of these families were prominent in politics, the military, literature, law, politics, medicine, and economics.

note.#text: 1919 Gansevoort-Lansing, Catherine; Ann P. Hays; John and Carolyn De Marco (Lyrical Ballad Bookstore); etc. Gift and purchase

The Gansevoorts and the Lansings were two of the original Dutch families to settle in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys of New York State. Other families who intermarried with the Gansevoorts and the Lansings were the Melvilles, Sanfords and Van Schaicks. Members of these families were prominent in politics, the military, literature, law, politics, medicine, and economics.

George Kennan 18-27 (October '94 - Aug.). Dr [Arthur Conan] Doyle 28-31 (October 1894 - January '95). M de Mauny Talvande 32 (Apr). Rev. Lyman Abbot 34-40 (October '94 - April '95). Wm. H. McElroy 42-48 (October '94 - May '95). Mark Twain 50-51 (July - August [1895]). Max O'Rell 52-57 (November '94 - April '95). Mary Proctor 59-67 (October '94 - July '95). Wm. Hamilton Gibson 69-76 (October '94 - May). Gen'l Lew Wallace 79-81 (January '95 - March). "Brownies in Fairyland" 82-87 (Sept '94 - Feb '95). Prof. H. H. Boyesen 90-92 (1895 Jan - 1895 Mar.). Dr. James Johnston 96-98 (Jan 94[i.e. '95]- Mar). George W. Cable 101-106 ([Oct. 1894] - March). Hamilton W. Mabie 107-111 (1894 Nov. - July). Alexander Black 112-118 (Nov - May). H. B. Thearle--Brownies 119-122 (Nov. - Feb 1895). Hamilton W. Mabie 123 (August). Thos. G. Allen 125-126 (Dec 1894, Feb 1895). David Christie Murray 129-132 (Dec - Mar). Capt. Jack Crawford 133-135 (Jany - Mar 1895). Frederick Villiers 137-140 (Jany - April 1895). Raffaëlli 141-142 ([March] - Apr). Alex Black 143-145 (1895 June - 1895 Aug). In addition, newspaper clippings from New-York Weekly Tribune, Saturday Oct. 6, 1860, "The Succession of Forest Trees," by Henry D. Thoreau. 2 leaves [one with section excised--material pasted onto pages 303, 306 and 313 of "The Dispersion of Seeds" below]. 1-45: 4 single, 9 double leaves, (of which, 1 with attachment, written on verso of John Brown notice)--The Dispersion of Seeds. 46-57: 7 small-format leaves--notes. 58-67a: 2 oversize leaves; 1 double leaf; 1 single leaf--on Huckleberries. 67b-95: 3 single leaves; 6 double leaves--The Dispersion of Seeds. 96-128: 11 single leaves; 3 double leaves--Journal entries, June 9, 54; June 10-13, 51; June 15, 54; June 16, 52; June 18, 52; June 18, 53. 129-138: 3 single leaves; 1 double leaf--Journal entries, May 13, 56; June 3, 56; Sep 24, 57; Mar 25, 55; Nov 10, 58; Oct 16, 57; Aug 30, 54; Jun 17, 60; Mar 5, 55; Ju[?] 28, 54; Sep 24, 57; Oct 6, 57; Ap 29, 57; Feb 14, 56; July 20, 60. 139-65: 3 single leaves; 5 double leaves (of which, 2 with attachments)--The Dispersion of Seeds. 166-193: 7 single leaves 1 double leaf--Dispersion of Seeds. 202-208: 4 single leaves (includes verso of John Brown and letter)--Dispersion of Seeds. 209-232: 7 single leaves; 2 double leaves (of these: 3 singles on verso of John Brown, foot of page in bad condition; 2 singles have one or more attachments/additional pages attached)--Journal / Dispersion. 233-235: 1 leaf with attachment--Notes on introduced plants. 236-245: 4 single leaves; 1 double leaf--Dispersion of Seeds. 247-399: 29 single leaves (4 with one or more attachments); 23 double leaves (5 with one or more attachments)--Journal/Dispersion. 400-411: 3 single leaves; 1 double leaf--notes, index notes. note.#text: 1919 Gansevoort-Lansing, Catherine; Ann P. Hays; John and Carolyn De Marco (Lyrical Ballad Bookstore); etc. Gift and purchase

The Gansevoorts and the Lansings were two of the original Dutch families to settle in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys of New York State. Other families who intermarried with the Gansevoorts and the Lansings were the Melvilles, Sanfords and Van Schaicks. Members of these families were prominent in politics, the military, literature, law, politics, medicine, and economics.
MSS 85M84
